docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. E. Cuyler Hammond, the biologist and epidemiologist who did early research showing that cigarette smokers had a high risk of death from lung cancer, heart disease and other causes, died yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. His family said he had died of cancer of the lymph system. He was 74 years old. Dr. Hammond, a courtly native of Baltimore, majored in biology as an undergraduate at Yale and earned a doctor of science degree in epidemiology from Johns Hopkins. He was director of the statisticial research section of the American Cancer Society from 1946 to 1966, when he became vice president for epidemiology and statistics, retiring in 1977. He was also, from 1953 to 1958, a professor of biometry -the science of statistics applied to biological observations - at Yale.
